Graphical abstract In this work, a series of Ni-Mg-Al catalysts with different Mg molar contents were prepared via a co-precipitation method. These catalysts were used for the biogas reforming of carbon dioxide (BRCD) for syngas production. The influence of Mg molar contents on the catalyst structure and catalytic performance was investigated. During the 60h stability test at 750°C, all of the Mg-promoted catalysts presented a higher catalytic activity and better stability in comparison with the catalyst without Mg loading. The NM10A sample with 10mol% Mg loading displayed the highest CH4 and CO2 conversion of 86.9% and 90.8%, respectively. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption analysis, XRD, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, TEM and TGA techniques. It was found that the addition of Mg inhibited the sintering of Ni particle and increased the catalyst basicity. Consequently this suppressed the coke deposition and improved the catalytic activity. The NM10A catalyst possessed the most basic sites, which caused a minimum amount carbon to be deposited on the catalyst and allowed for the best catalytic activity. The obvious increase of the Ni metal size and the severe coke deposition resulted in the deactivation of the NM0A catalyst. Keywords Biogas reforming Ni based catalysts Mg promoter Basic sites Carbon deposition 1 Introduction The depletion of world fossil fuel resources and an increase of greenhouse gas emissions shows the necessity for developing and expanding sustainable and renewable energy sources. An attractive energy source is biogas [1], whereby it is produced through the anaerobic digestion or fermentation of widely available organic matter, such as sewage, energy crops, agricultural wastes, domestic refuse and animal manures. The components of biogas are mainly methane (CH4, 55–65%) and carbon dioxide (CO2, 30–45%) [2]. Currently, biogas is mainly applied in heating and producing electricity, which is not effective enough for utilizing biogas energy [3]. Therefore, more applications of biogas are desirable. One attractive approach is to convert biogas by using catalytic reforming (called as biogas reforming), which has the potential to take full advantage of biogas by converting both CH4 and CO2 (the two principle greenhouse gases) into H2 and CO, or syngas. Syngas can be used as a major feedstock in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to produce several valuable petrochemicals and fuels [4–6]. In light of the above considerations, previous research has confirmed that the biogas reforming is a suitable technology to generate synthesis gas [7]. Rathod and Bhale [8] investigated the performance of upgrading model biogas (60% CH4, 40% CO2) to syngas using a γ-Al2O3 based nickel catalyst, and the H2/CO ratio of one was obtained at 800°C. Bereketidou and Goula [9] studied the reforming of a clean model biogas with a constant molar CH4/CO2 ratio of 1.5 over nickel catalysts supported on alumina and ceria. It was found that the 8wt% nickel catalyst supported on 20wt% ceria-alumina was proven to have the best catalytic performance with a H2/CO ratio of approximately 1.3. It is noteworthy that almost all biogas reforming studies were based on model biogas (55–65% CH4, 30–45% CO2) simulated with methane and carbon dioxide. Thus, in order to provide more convictive evidence for the utilization of biogas in the reforming field, we proposed to apply real biogas derived from the food waste (with purification) in the reforming reaction for syngas production. This work also differs from previous studies by using a CH4/CO2 ratio of one by employing another feedstock, carbon dioxide. A previous study has shown that a CH4/CO2 ratio of one was favored to produce H2 and CO at the ratio of one, which was more suitable for the production of oxygenated hydrocarbons via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [10]. Besides, it has also been stated that excessive CH4 was inclined to coke deposition and easily induced catalyst deactivation, and thus decreased the conversion of biogas [11]. In consideration of these differences, we named the reforming reaction in this study the biogas reforming of carbon dioxide (BRCD), which can be considered to be analogous to the dry reforming of methane (DRM). The DRM reaction is a highly endothermic reaction showed in Eq. (1). (1) CH4 +CO2 ⇌2CO+2H2 (ΔH298k =247kJ/mol) Some catalysts based on noble metals such as Pt, Rh and Ir have been reported to exhibit a high catalytic activity and have an excellent resistance to carbon deposition in the DRM reaction [12–15]. However, high cost and low availability restrict their use in large-scale applications [16]. Thus, the development of non-noble metal based catalysts have obtained much attention. Among them, Ni-based catalysts have been considered as one of the most promising candidates because of their low cost and high activity [17]. However, the main obstacle of using a nickel-based catalyst is the high thermodynamic potential for carbon deposition, consequently inducing the catalyst deactivation [18,19]. The coke originates mainly from the methane decomposition (CH4 ⇌C+2H2, ΔH298k =75kJ/mol) and CO disproportionation (2CO⇌C+CO2, ΔH298k =−171kJ/mol). Previous studies have reported that the carbon deposition is suppressed by introducing alkaline earth metal oxides, which can increase the basic sites of the catalyst and improve the ability of the CO2 adsorption and consequently inhibit the catalyst deactivation [20]. Recently, Son et al. [21] reported that the conversions of CO2 and CH4 over MgO promoted Co-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst were much higher than these over Co-Ni/Al2O3 under the same reaction conditions. Xu et al. [22] claimed that the MgO-promoted catalysts exhibited a better thermal stability and CO2 chemisorption ability which resulted in a higher catalytic activity and better coke-resistant performance. Considering the excellent performance of the catalyst supported with MgO, a detailed understanding of the effect of the Mg promoter on the catalyst structure and catalytic performance is desired. Notably, the catalytic performance was also influenced by the catalyst preparation method. In recent years, several synthesis methods of the catalyst have been utilized, such as sol-gel, wet impregnation, co-precipitation, and hydrothermal [7,23]. The co-precipitation method has been extensively used as a facile and promising method, which could lead to a high surface area and mesopores structure of the catalyst. In this study, in comparison to the conventional co-precipitation method, a reflux process (aging in hot water for a certain time) was applied. This process not only favored to produce the homogenized crystals but also enhanced the interfaces between nickel and support. These attributes were beneficial to the catalytic activity and stability [24]. In this research, a Ni-Mg-Al catalyst system was prepared using a refluxed co-precipitation method and was investigated using various Mg molar concentrations with the BRCD reaction. The aim of this study was not only to optimize the content of Mg promoter, but also to provide valuable reference data for further applications involving the reformation of raw biogas to syngas. The catalyst characterization was obtained using various techniques including N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, TEM and TGA in order to investigate the structural properties and basicity of the catalyst, and the type of deposited carbon over different catalysts. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of Ni-Mg-Al catalysts with different Mg molar contents (0, 5, 10, 20 and 30mol%) were synthesized using a refluxed co-precipitation method. In this research, the metallic nitrates (Sigma-Aldrich), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (98.5%), Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (99%), and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (98%) were used as the Ni, Mg and Al precursor, respectively. These metallic nitrates were jointly dissolved in distilled water to obtain a 0.2molL−1 reagent solution. A NaOH aqueous solution (1molL−1) was used as the precipitant. Then the two solutions were added drop-wise into 50mL distilled water at 40°C with a constant pH of 11.00±0.05. Thereafter, the obtained slurry was poured into a round-bottom flask and the slurry was crystallized with a refluxing temperature of 80°C for 24h, after which the precipitate was washed with distilled water until the pH was 7.00±0.05 and collected by vacuum filtration. Subsequently, the resulting precipitate was dried at 110°C for 12h and calcined in air at 850°C for 4h. Finally, the Ni-Mg-Al mixed oxides were tableted, ground, and sieved with a 40–60mesh size. The content of Ni was fixed at 11mol% and the Mg molar contents varied from 0 to 30mol% in the calcined catalyst. The catalysts are denoted as NMxA, where x represents the molar percentage of Mg. 2.2 Characterization The N2 adsorption/desorption analysis was completed using a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 (Quantachrome Instruments, Boynton Beach, FL). Approximately 0.1g of catalyst was used for each analysis. The specific surface area and pore size distribution were obtained using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda methods, respectively. The total pore volume was estimated from the maximum adsorption point at P/P0 =0.99. Prior to the measurement, the degasification of the catalysts was conducted at 300°C for 9h. In situ XRD analysis was performed to characterize the change of crystalline phases during reduction process for the NM10A catalyst using Beamline 17-BM (λ=0.72768Å) at the Advanced Photon Source at the Argonne National Laboratory. The calcined catalyst was reduced from room temperature to 850°C with a heating rate of 5°Cmin−1 and kept at this temperature for 2h in 3.5% H2/He at a flow rate of 30mLmin−1. The XRD profiles were successively obtained with a scanning rate of 5°s−1 from 5° to 45°. The derivative equation of Bragg Law (Eq. (2)) transfers the 2θ1 value obtained on in-situ XRD analysis (λ1 =0.72768Å) into the general 2θ2 value (λ2 =1.5406Å) which can be conveniently identified by comparing the results with those included in the International Centre for Diffraction Data (ICDD). Ex-situ XRD analysis was conducted using an Ultima III XRD (Rigaku Americas, The Woodlands, TX) with CuKα radiation (λ=1.5406Å) generated at 40kV and 44mA at a scanning rate of 3°min−1 from 10° to 90° to obtain the crystalline phases of all catalysts after calcination, reduction and the 60h time-on-stream test. (2) θ 2 = arcsin ( λ 2 λ 1 sin θ 1 ) The morphology of the reduced and used catalyst was characterized using a JEOL JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope (TEM, Waterford, VA) operated at 200kV. Samples were prepared by suspending the catalysts in ethanol with an ultrasonic treatment for 30min. Subsequently, 1–3 drop(s) of suspension was dropped onto a copper microscope grid (300mesh) covered with formvar and carbon. The amount of carbon deposited on the used catalysts was determined using a thermogravimetric analyzer (Shimadzu TGA-50, Columbia, MD). Approximately 6mg of the used catalyst was heated from room temperature to 1000°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min in air. 2.3 Activity measurement The BRCD reaction was carried out in a quartz tube fixed-bed reactor as reported previously by Bao et al. [17]. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced at 850°C for 2h in 50% H2/N2 at a flow rate of 50mLmin−1. Raw biogas was obtained from Quasar Energy Group, Columbus, OH. This raw biogas consisted of 62.7% CH4, 23.5% CO2, 11.2% N2 and 2.6% O2. Before being fed into the reactor, the biogas was purified to remove O2 by using a Cu based catalyst [25]. The purified biogas consisted 63.8% CH4, 24.1% CO2, and 12.1% N2. Carbon dioxide was added to make a stoichiometric feed with a CH4/CO2 ratio of 1. Approximately 50mg of catalyst particles (40–60mesh) were employed for the catalytic test using temperatures ranging from 650°C to 800°C in steps of 50°C. To investigate the stability of the catalysts, the reaction was conducted at 750°C using a GHSV of 28,000mLg−1 h−1. The feed gas and tail gas were analyzed on-line by using an Agilent 7890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID) (specifications of the Agilent 7890 can be seen in a previous study) [26]. The conversions of CO2 and CH4, the H2/CO ratio were calculated as defined in Eqs. ((3)–(5)). (3) Conv.CH4 (%)=([CH4]in −[N2]in[CH4]out/[N2]out)/[CH4]in ×100 (4) Conv.CO2 (%)=([CO2]in −[N2]in[CO2]out/[N2]out)/[CO2]in ×100 (5) H2/CO=[H2]out/[CO]out The nitrogen in the gas was used as an internal standard for the conversion calculations. [CH4]in is the concentration of the CH4 in the inlet gas, [CH4]out is the concentration of CH4 in the effluent gas, [N2]in is the concentration of N2 in the inlet gas, [N2]out is the concentration of N2 in the effluent gas, [CO2]in is the concentration of the CO2 in the inlet gas, [CO2]out is the concentration of CO2 in the effluent gas, [H2]out is the concentration of H2 in the effluent gas, and [CO]out is the concentration of CO in the effluent gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Ni-Mg-Al catalysts 3.1.1 Physical properties of the catalyst Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the reduced Ni-Mg-Al catalysts. In Fig. 1a, the N2 isotherms of all reduced catalysts exhibited type IV isotherms with H1 shaped steep hysteresis loops in the range of 0.6–0.9 (p/p0), which suggested these catalysts belonged to the mesoporous material according to the IUPAC classification. As seen in Fig. 1b, the all reduced catalysts showed a mesoporous structure with a pore size located in the range of 2–10nm. The NM0A catalyst showed the narrowest pore size distribution, and increasing the Mg molar content shifted the pore size distribution to a larger size. Table 1 presented the physical properties of reduced catalysts with different Mg molar contents. As obtained, the NM0A catalyst without Mg promoter showed the largest BET surface area and the maximum pore volume. With the introduction of Mg promoter, a relatively smaller value of BET surface area and pore volume was displayed. This showed that the addition of the Mg alkaline promoter into the Ni-Al catalyst system could not induce the improvement of physical properties. It’s worth noting that the BET surface area would influence the catalyst’s ability of CO2 chemisorption, which would be discussed later (see Sec. 3.1.4). 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) X-ray diffraction experiments were conducted to analyze the crystallite phases in the prepared catalysts. The ex-situ XRD patterns of the Ni-Mg-Al catalysts after calcination at 850°C are depicted in Fig. 2 a. As can be seen in Fig. 2a, the XRD patterns of the NM0A catalyst showed the diffraction peaks at 2θ° of 44.5°, 51.9° and 76.4°, which were attributed to the NiO phase (ICDD 78-0643). The characteristic peaks of the NiAl2O4 spinel structure (ICDD 78-0552) at 2θ° of 37.0°, 44.9°, 59.6° and 65.5° were also detected. For the catalysts with Mg loading, apart from the two phases mentioned above, the characteristic peaks of the MgAl2O4 spinel structure (ICDD 21-1152), MgO (ICDD 45-0946) and MgNiO2 (ICDD 24-0712) were also observed. However, due to the overlapping of MgO and MgNiO2 characteristic peaks, it was hard to distinguish them [27]. According to the following H2-TPR results (see Fig. 3 ), MgNiO2 existed in the catalysts with Mg loading due to the major reduction peak shifts to higher temperature in comparison with the catalyst without Mg loading. The ex-situ XRD patterns of the Ni-Mg-Al catalysts after reduction at 850°C are shown in Fig. 2b. The characteristic peaks at 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.4° for all the reduced catalysts were related to Ni metal phase (ICDD 04-0850), which was the active site for BRCD reaction. Ni particle size of all catalysts is presented in Table 1. The Ni particle size of the catalysts containing Mg were smaller than the NM0A catalyst, indicating that the doping of Mg inhibited the sintering of the Ni phase, which had a positive effect on catalytic activity [28]. The XRD patterns of the catalysts with a lower Mg molar content (5 and 10mol%), and the diffraction peaks assigned to MgNiO2 were not found, implying the absence of MgNiO2. Nevertheless, the diffraction peaks 2θ° at 62.3°correspond to MgNiO2 and were detected in the XRD patterns of the catalysts with a higher Mg molar content (20 and 30mol%). The intensity of this peak increased with the increase of the Mg molar content from 20 to 30mol%. To investigate the change of crystalline phases during the reduction process in detail, the NM10A catalyst was selected to be applied in the in-situ XRD analysis due to it having the best catalytic performance in Fig. 6. The in-situ XRD patterns of the NM10A reduced from room temperature (RT) to 850°C are shown in Fig. 2c. With reduction temperature increasing from RT to 650°C, the diffraction peaks representing NiO and MgO (or MgNiO2) did not show an obvious change. As the reduction temperature increased continuously to 750°C, the intensity of those peaks decreased; concurrently, the diffraction peaks assigned to the Ni metal phase occurred. It was reported that the required reduction temperature of pure NiO to Ni was around 300–500°C [29]. However, in this work, the Ni metal phase did not occur until the reduction temperature increased to 750°C, indicating the strong interaction between NiO and support [30]. After reduction at 850°C for 2h, the diffraction peaks assigned to NiO and MgNiO2 could not be found, which were consistent with the ex-situ XRD results of the reduced NM10A catalyst in Fig. 2b. Meanwhile, NiAl2O4 and MgAl2O4 existed continually in this reduction process. It’s worth noting that the presence of NiAl2O4 in reduced catalysts impacted positively on the inhibition of Ni sintering and the stabilization of Ni particles at a high reaction temperature. Lu et al. reported that the stabilizing effect of NiAl2O4 was most likely due to the strong bonding between nickel and NiAl2O4. Meanwhile, the nickel aluminate bonded well to the support Al2O3 and was effectively incorporated into the surface of the alumina support [31]. However, it was also believed that the NiAl2O4 spinel cannot be easily reduced to Ni0+ (confirmed by Fig. 3) and thus its formation lowered the amount of active Ni and catalyst activity [32]. Koo et al. stated that the presence of MgAl2O4 spinel could prevents NiAl2O4 formation and favored a high catalyst activity and stability in the DRM reaction [33]. In addition, the formation of MgAl2O4 spinel exerted a positive effect on the enhancement of CO2 adsorption and therefore provided more oxygen species on the surface of the catalysts, which would be discussed at Sec. 3.1.4. 3.1.3 H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The H2-TPR measurement was employed to investigate the reducibility of Ni-Mg-Al catalysts with different Mg molar contents after calcination at 850°C, and the results are depicted in Fig. 3. The interaction strength between the metal and the support had a significant influence on the TPR profiles of nickel based catalysts [34]. In general, the reduction peak of the NiO species would shift to higher temperatures when the metal-support interaction existed in the catalyst system. Zhang et al. [35] investigated the reducibility of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with different Ni/Al ratios calcined at 500°C for 5h. They found that free NiO, scarcely interacting with Al2O3, reduced in the temperature range of 300°C to 500°C. Hadian et al. [36] investigated the reducibility of the Ni/MgAl2O4 catalysts with different Ni loadings calcined at 600°C for 4h. The TPR profiles revealed that the reduction peak at a temperature around 800°C was an indication of a strong interaction between NiO and Al2O3. In this work, all the catalysts did not show the reduction peak at lower temperature (300–500°C) and showed only one major reduction peak in the region of 770–870°C, indicating that NiO strongly interacted with Al2O3 after calcination at a temperature of 850°C. The absence of the reduction peak at a lower temperature and the presence of the reduction peak at temperatures above 750°C were consistent with the in-situ XRD results (see Fig. 2c) which exhibited the Ni metal phase appeared at the reduction temperature above 750°C. Compared with the NM0A catalyst, the addition of Mg promoter shifted the major peak toward a higher temperature, which suggested the formation of the spinel-like MgNiO2 species due to the strong metal-support interaction between NiO and MgO. In the case of the NM0A catalyst, another reduction peak occurred at around 950°C, which could be related to the reduction of bulk NiAl2O4 [37]. In contrast, the reduction peak of bulk NiAl2O4 was not visible in the catalysts with Mg loading, which was due to the limit of the reduction temperature in the H2-TPR experiment. In this work, all catalysts were reduced at 850°C which was lower than the required temperature to reduce the bulk NiAl2O4, meaning that bulk NiAl2O4 still existed in the reduced catalysts, which was confirmed by the XRD results in Fig. 2b and c. In the case of the catalysts containing Mg, the temperatures of reduction peaks were below 850°C when catalysts contained lower Mg contents (5 and 10mol%). Comparatively, in the catalysts with higher Mg contents (20 and 30mol%), the temperatures of reduction peaks were above 850°C. This finding suggests that the spinel-like MgNiO2 would be reduced totally and did not exist in the reduced NM5A and NM10A catalysts while still existing in the reduced NM20A and NM30A catalysts, which was consistent with XRD results. Notably, the formation of MgNiO2 would obstruct the reduction of Ni2+, resulting in less available Ni sites (active sites for the BRCD reaction) and lower catalytic activity [38]. 3.1.4 CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) CO2-TPD experiments were conducted to determine the surface basicity of the reduced Ni-Mg-Al catalysts with different Mg molar contents, and the results are displayed in Fig. 4 . It is generally believed that a higher desorption temperature of CO2 reflects a stronger basicity and a larger amount of CO2 desorption while indicating that more basic sites are available on the surface of catalyst [39]. In all samples, three main CO2 desorption peaks were detected in the tested temperature range (from 50 to 750°C), which indicated that three types of basic sites were presented in the reduced Ni-Mg-Al catalysts. The weak, medium, and strong basic sites were estimated from the desorption peaks in the temperature range of 100–200°C, 200–350°C and 350–600°C, respectively. These desorption peaks were calculated and are summarized in Table 2 . Compared with the NM0A catalyst, all of the catalysts with the Mg promoter presented a higher amount of desorbed CO2, indicating that more basic sites were produced. The intensity of desorbed CO2 increased until the Mg molar content increased to 10mol%, and then the intensity of desorbed CO2 decreased as the Mg molar content continuously increased to 30mol%. As reported in many studies [40–42], the capacity of CO2 adsorption on the Al2O3 supported Ni-based catalyst was influenced greatly by the addition of alkali elements and the specific surface area; and the formation of MgAl2O4 phase also influenced the catalyst surface basic site density in the NiO-MgO-Al2O3 catalyst system [43]. Seo et al. stated the forming process of the highly basic surface magnesium aluminate: when introduced MgO into NiO-Al2O3 catalyst system, the uniformly incorporated Mg2+ in the Al2O3 lattice created a surface defect in order to compensate the positive charge generated, and consequently the adjacent surface oxygen ion became coordinately unsaturated, resulting in highly basic surface of the obtained sample [44]. Basic nature of the MgAl2O4 phase will increase the chemisorption of CO2, which was beneficial for the catalytic activity providing the oxygen to form CO and also causing the elimination of the coke. As for the NM0A catalyst, although the NM0A catalyst showed the largest BET surface area (see Table 1), the absence of the Mg promoter caused the smallest amount of basic sites to develop on this catalyst and resulted in the smallest amount of adsorbed CO2. The NM10A catalyst possessed the best capacity of CO2 adsorption not only because it had a relatively larger BET surface area, which allowed CO2 to have more opportunity to be adsorbed on a surface basic site. It was also because the addition of Mg promoter and meanwhile the formation of the MgAl2O4 phase, which increased the catalyst surface basic sites. More basic sites favored the chemisorption and activation of CO2, which provided more oxygen on the surface of the catalysts and thus helped the removal of intermediated carbon from the CH4 decomposition and CO disproportionation. Therefore, catalyst’s ability to resist carbon deposition could be improved in the reforming process. The proposed process of CO2 chemisorption and deposited carbon gasification was depicted in Fig. 5 . 3.1.5 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) The reduced NM10A catalyst was selected to undergo TEM characterization to analyze its morphologies based on this catalyst having the best catalytic activity and stability (see Fig. 7 ). The results are shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 6a shows a homogenous distribution of Ni metal particles assembled over the support. The Ni particle size varied from 3nm to 13nm and was mainly distributed at the 4–8nm range (Fig. 6a insertion). Furthermore, direct evidence of the elements distribution of the reduced NM10A catalyst was obtained by using the scanning transmission mode (STEM) analysis. Energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) mapping showed that each element (nickel, magnesium, aluminum and oxygen) was homogenously distributed in the reduced NM10A catalyst (Fig. 6b). The homogenous distribution of Ni metal particles is considerably beneficial to enhance the sintering-resistance and coke-resistance of the catalyst and thus favor the improvement of activity and stability in the BRCD reaction [45]. In Fig. 6c, the (111) plane of Ni crystal with a d-spacing of 0.20nm was observed clearly in the reduced NM10A catalyst by the HRTEM characterization. The selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) result of the reduced NM10A catalyst (Fig. 6d) revealed that diffraction rings corresponding to Ni [(111) and (200)], Al2O3 [(400) and (440)], MgAl2O4 (511) and NiAl2O4 (311) coexisted in the sample, which was consistent with the in-situ XRD result of the reduced NM10A catalyst in Fig. 2c. 3.2 Catalyst performance The catalytic activities of the Ni-Mg-Al catalysts for the BRCD reaction were examined ranging from 650°C to 800°C at the same GHSV of 28,000mLg−1 h−1 for each reactant gas. Fig. 7a shows that as the reaction temperature increased from 650°C to 800°C, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 over the catalysts loaded with Mg increased due to the endothermic nature of the BRCD reaction [46]. However, the CH4 and CO2 conversion of the catalyst without the Mg promoter decreased when the reaction temperature increased to 800°C. This resulted from catalyst deactivation because of the carbon deposition from methane decomposition and CO disproportionation [47]. This indicates that the introduction of the Mg promoter in nickel based catalysts plays a critical role of inhibiting coke formation and enhancing the catalytic activity, especially at a high reaction temperature. Considering the great thermo stability of MgAl2O4 spinel phase, the notable enhancement of catalytic activity was likely related to the formation of MgAl2O4 in the Ni-Mg-Al catalyst system, which favored potentially the Ni stability and restrained its sintering. As for the catalysts loaded with Mg, the catalytic conversion of CO2 was higher than the paralleled CH4 conversion, and the H2/CO ratios were lower than one, indicating the occurrence of the RWGS reaction (CO2 +H2 ⇌CO+H2O, ΔH298k =41kJ/mol) [48]. This generated a lower H2 concentration and a higher CO concentration in the tail gas. The H2/CO ratio increased slightly with the increase of reaction temperature in the catalysts with the Mg promoter. A higher temperature favored the predominance of the methane decomposition reaction because of its endothermic characterization, which produced more H2 and coke and resulted in a greater H2/CO ratio. Meanwhile, the formed coke was removed by the reverse Boudouard reaction (CO2 +C⇌2CO, ΔH298k =171kJ/mol) and carbon gasification (H2O+C⇌CO+H2, ΔH298k =131kJ/mol) [49]. These aforementioned reactions contributed to the absence of coke formation which was not observed on the surface of these catalysts (see Figs. 8 and 9 ). To provide insight into the durability of the Ni-Mg-Al catalysts involved with the BRCD reaction, long-term stability tests were carried out at 750°C for 60h, and the results are depicted in Fig. 7b. Fig. 7b shows that the NM0A catalyst presented the poorest stability, which was related to the catalyst deactivation caused by the deposited coke from methane decomposition and CO disproportionation (confirmed by the TGA results in Fig. 6). Without Mg loading, the NM0A catalyst possessed the smallest number of basic sites (verified by the CO2-TPD results in Fig. 4), which resulted in the poor capacity of CO2 chemisorption. As a consequence, the removal of deposited carbon due to the reverse Boudouard reaction was reduced, and subsequently copious amounts of Ni metal, the active sites for the BRCD reaction, was covered by carbon which induced the deactivation of the NM0A catalyst. According to the XRD results in Fig. 8c and Table 3 , the growth of the Ni metal size during the BRCD reaction was also responsible for its deactivation. Fig. 7b shows that all catalysts with Mg loading presented highly stable catalytic activities. In addition, the feed gas conversion increased as the Mg molar content increased from 5 to 10mol%, and then it decreased with incremental Mg loadings. The NM10A catalyst was responsible for the maximum CH4 and CO2 conversions of 86.9% and 90.8%, respectively. Based on the CO2-TPD spectra (Fig. 4), as the Mg loading increased from 5 to 10mol%, the basic sites on the surface of the catalysts were improved and therefore the capability of CO2 adsorption was enhanced which was favorable for the BRCD reaction. However, the excessive Mg loading caused a loss of BET surface area (see Table 1) and decreased the adsorption of CO2, which resulted in a decreased catalytic activity. A lower catalytic activity of the NM20A and NM30A catalysts was also caused by the fact that the reduced NM20A and NM30A catalysts possessed the MgNiO2 phase (see Figs. 2 and 3) which had a negative effect on catalytic activity due to the less available Ni metal sites for the BRCD reaction. 3.3 Characterization of the used catalysts The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the catalysts after the 60h stability test are shown in Fig. 8a and b. All of the used catalysts exhibited type IV isotherms with H1-shaped hysteresis loops and displayed narrow pore size distribution curves. This indicated that the mesoporous framework was successfully preserved during the 60h stability test. The pore size distribution of each sample shifted to smaller sizes after being on stream for 60h when compared with the reduced catalyst. In addition, the physical properties of these used catalysts were summarized in Table 3. In comparison with the reduced NM0A catalyst, the sample which underwent reactions for 60h had a smaller BET surface area, smaller total pore volume and smaller average pore size. This was due to the deposition of carbon which blocked some mesoporous channels and consequently negatively affected these physical properties. The catalysts with a Mg promoter only had a slight decrease in BET surface area, indicating that the presence of Mg obviously suppressed the blocking of mesoporous channels by deposited carbon. The XRD patterns of all catalysts that underwent reactions are illustrated in Fig. 8c. In comparison with the corresponding reduced catalysts, the peaks of metallic nickel in all catalysts that underwent reactions on stream were sharper, indicating that the Ni particle size increased during the BRCD reaction. Direct evidence of the increased Ni particle size is displayed in Table 3. The metallic Ni particle size of the NM0A catalyst which underwent reactions on stream was larger than that of the catalysts which underwent reactions containing Mg, suggesting the sintering of metallic Ni particles was inhibited effectively with the addition of the Mg promoter. The NM20A and NM30A catalysts which underwent reactions on stream resulted in the NiMgO2 phase remaining in the catalyst, which was related to their lower catalytic activities because less Ni metal sites were formed. The characteristic peaks of carbon at 2θ° of 26.2° were clearly observed in the NM0A catalyst. However, in other catalysts, carbon was not detected. Considering the limitation of XRD detection, it could be deduced that no carbon or trace content of carbon was deposited on these catalysts during the BRCD reaction. In order to provide a clearer understanding of the carbon deposition on the catalysts, the TGA analysis was performed, and the results are summarized in Fig. 8d. There were some increases for TG profiles of all used catalysts in the range of 200°C–400°C. This is caused by the oxidation of the metallic Ni active sites [50]. Meanwhile, as for all the used catalysts, the TG profiles consisted of a predominate mass loss at a temperature range of 400°C–750°C, fully attributable to carbon combustion [23]. This shows that a carbon phase was deposited over all the catalysts during the BRCD reaction. The minimum and maximum mass loss was obtained with the NM10A and NM0A catalyst, respectively. In order to evaluate the type of deposited carbon on the surface of used catalyst, the TEM and EDS mapping analysis of the two representative catalyst (the NM0A and NM10A catalyst after 60h stability test) was conducted and the results were depicted in Fig. 9. It was noticeable that the filamentous carbon was deposited on the surfaces of each catalyst and the NM10A catalyst showed much less carbon deposition than NM0A, as proved by XRD and TGA. From the above results, it can be clearly seen that the introduction of the Mg promoter greatly decreased the mass loss, suggesting the Mg basic modifier played a substantial role in inhibiting the coke deposition. Based on the discussion in the Sec. 3.1.4, the positive effect on the inhibition of deposited carbon in the Ni-Mg-Al catalyst system was caused by the increased surface basic intensity, which improved the chemisorption and activation of CO2. Therefore the coke elimination was accelerated by the reverse Boudouard reaction and the deposited carbon was decreased. 4 Conclusions A series of Ni-Mg-Al catalysts with different Mg molar contents were prepared via a co-precipitation method. These catalysts were used for the biogas reforming of carbon dioxide (BRCD) for syngas production. The catalytic performance of the Ni-Mg-Al catalysts was investigated in the BRCD reaction. Among all the Mg-promoted catalysts, the reduced NM10A catalyst presented the best structural properties. This catalyst also possessed the strongest basicity, which was responsible for its highest catalytic activity and incurred the smallest amount of carbon deposition when compared with the other catalysts. The NM20A and NM30A catalysts had a slightly lower catalytic activity, which was related to the decreased availability of Ni metal sites due to the formation of the MgNiO2 phase. As for the NM0A catalyst, the significant growth of Ni metal size and the large amount of deposited carbon caused its fast deactivation during the 60h reforming test. Compared with the NM0A catalyst without the Mg modifier, all Mg-doped catalysts displayed a better catalytic activity and stability with a stronger resistance to coke formation during the 60h time-on-stream test. This is attributed to the incorporation of the Mg basic promoter, which inhibited the sintering of the Ni metal phase and intensified the surface basicity. This improved the CO2 chemisorption and accelerated the coke removal which facilitated the reforming process. These features show that the Ni-Al catalysts with the Mg promoter can be used as promising candidates for biogas reforming of carbon dioxide. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a series of Ni-Mg-Al catalysts with different Mg molar contents were prepared via a co-precipitation method. These catalysts were used for the biogas reforming of carbon dioxide (BRCD) for syngas production. The influence of Mg molar contents on the catalyst structure and catalytic performance was investigated. During the 60h stability test at 750°C, all of the Mg-promoted catalysts presented a higher catalytic activity and better stability in comparison with the catalyst without Mg loading. The NM10A sample with 10mol% Mg loading displayed the highest CH4 and CO2 conversion of 86.9% and 90.8%, respectively. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption analysis, XRD, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, TEM and TGA techniques. It was found that the addition of Mg inhibited the sintering of Ni particle and increased the catalyst basicity. Consequently this suppressed the coke deposition and improved the catalytic activity. The NM10A catalyst possessed the most basic sites, which caused a minimum amount carbon to be deposited on the catalyst and allowed for the best catalytic activity. The obvious increase of the Ni metal size and the severe coke deposition resulted in the deactivation of the NM0A catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Biogas reforming of carbon dioxide to syngas production over Ni-Mg-Al catalysts
